Lennox Middle School students recently participated in "Peak Performance: Soccer," a week-long journalism and sports science summer camp at The Accelerated School and the University of Southern California. Peak
Performance: Soccer builds on children's experience with My Voice Matters, Lennox Middle School’s journalism class.

There were 10 kids from LMS and 10 kids from The Accelerated School in South Central who participated. LMS students learned about nutrition and the science behind soccer. They also had the opportunity to visit the Banc of California Stadium, learning about what it takes to run a stadium, learning about the press room, meeting their falcon and hawk, and finally, reporting on a Watch Party for the US Women’s World Cup. Our LMS students interviewed many people and did some live reporting on the event. Incredible!!

Parents and families were invited on the last day for a small reception and ceremony. Congratulations to all students who were selected to participate in this amazing program!

We recently heard the unfortunate news about Dr. Glen Langer, long-time mentor for Lennox students, who passed away. Dr. Glenn Langer, Head of Cardiology at the UCLA Medical School, along with his wife started a mentoring program in 1996 for seven students from Lennox Middle School with their own funding.

Since then, the program has grown considerably and has extended to several more schools, touching the lives of many. To this day, his program (Partnership Scholarship Program) is still active and many families from LMS benefit from the services. Our hearts go out to his family, friends, and the Lennox community. We are eternally grateful for Dr. Langer and his family’s commitment and dedication to empower and support our students.

Farnoosh L. Aguilar has been a principal at Buford Elementary School for 3 years and has been working in our district for 20 years. Her favorite part of her job is seeing students grow and learn not only academically, but personally.

“Most of our students are here for six years and we are so lucky to watch them mature and develop into themselves right before our eyes,” she says. “I want students to leave Buford confident and prepared for all that life has waiting for them!”

In her free time, Farnoosh likes to slow down from her busy work days by doing yoga or traveling with friends and family.

Moffett Elementary School Principal Oscar Cisneros has been working in the Lennox School District for 5 years. He did not take the common path to become a teacher and principal. He worked 10 years as a security officer and landscaper, working graveyard shifts full time while also attending school full-time.

Now, he has five college degrees (AA, BA, MA, MS, MA) and is following his passion of finding ways to help inspire and help children and families discover their true potential. He wants to help them become a version of themselves that seeks to realize that potential. This is inspired partly by "The Masai Greeting” story.

International Woman's Day is Celebrated once a year on March 8 and the month of March is recognized as Women's History Month. This year, our Felton Parent Volunteers were inspired by a quote, "Here's to strong women, may we know them, may we be them, may we raise them." They wanted to share that message with Felton girls to remind them that they can be whatever they set their minds to.

Volunteers collaborated with Parent Liaison Karen Rodriguez and Library Technician Maria Fernandez to host an arts and craft activity this week. After learning about influential women in history, students wrote words on flower petals to describe girls and women, putting them together to create a flower. Most girls shared that they were thinking about their moms. Very heartwarming!

#WomensHistoryMonth InternationalWomensDay

This year, our Felton Parent Volunteers were inspired by a quote, "Here's to strong women, may we know them, may we be them, may we raise them." They wanted to share that message with Felton girls to remind them that they can be whatever they set their minds to.

Volunteers collaborated with Parent Liaison Karen Rodriguez and Library Technician Maria Fernandez to host an arts and craft activity this week. After learning about influential women in history, students wrote words on flower petals to describe girls and women, putting them together to create a flower. Most girls shared that they were thinking about their moms. Very heartwarming!

At Lennox Middle School, no day is a boring day. Moffett Elementary School Counselor Luz Arce conducts Social Skills groups with the help of Counselor Assistant Stefani Macias. Lessons are designed with the children’s stages of development in mind. The Counseling Center has been equipped with puppets, games, books, crafts, and posters that creates a safe and caring environment. For example, last week the hot cocoa cup mindfulness lesson was delivered to the students. The objective of the lesson is for students to learn the definition of mindfulness, participate in a mindfulness exercise, and be able to identify at least two things that bring them joy.

Ms. Arce leads the students through a calm and soothing exercise. Students learned to breathe in through their nose and out through their mouth. By the end of the exercise, students were relaxed, calm, and were opened minded. Thank you Ms. Arce for helping our students build invaluable skills they can use inside and outside of the classrooms!

Rachel Romero is highly committed to increasing student academic success at Dolores Huerta Elementary School and everyone notices. For example, she motivates and supports student challenges through daily responsibility contracts tailored to the needs of each child. The responsibility contract strengthens the partnership between counselor, teacher, and student. The consistency of the daily contracts promotes student organization and responsibility, allowing Ms. Romero to focus on individual student success plans.

Once a student reaches 10 days of "perfect" completed responsibility contracts, they celebrate with a small pizza lunch party in their honor. The ultimate goal is to develop excellent student habits that will become intrinsic and lead to long-term student academic success. Thank you, Rachel, for your tireless effort to guide our students towards success!

Jefferson Elementary Counselor Emily Polk believes that the most powerful tool we all possess is our ability to connect and develop relationships with students.

“By forming connected relationships with caring adults, students are able to grow, heal, and maximize their potential as lifelong learners,” Emily says. Because of this belief, Emily founded the Juntos Wellness Center in 2012 with a vision of strengthening opportunities for students to get the social-emotional support they need and deserve.

Just for fun: On rainy days, everything and anything can happen! Pictured here is Emily guiding students to their classrooms after they had lunch. With the rain coming down so hard, she makes sure to bring a large umbrella to help keep the students dry. Thank you, Emily, for all that you do!
